captions.text:
Two female U.S. tourists got arrested after
they defaced the Colosseum in Rome in fact

the two women carved out their initials and
they got caught immediately according to the

Guardian the Californians aged 21 and 25 snuck
away from the their tour group on Saturday

and began scratching their initials into the
amphitheatre with a coin they managed a J

and an N around 8cm high before taking a selfie
with their handiwork genius gee I wonder if

they have an evidence on them now before we
go to I don't want to get to eh ugly American

tourist thing cause I know that there's a
lot of people that are thinking that let me

just note that recently OK last year in fact
there were people from Australia, Brazil,

and Canada that were also caught doing the
same thing and the results in a story in some

Russians doing some defacing so don't hate
on the Americans in this case it's not unique

to American tourists turns out weren't homo
sapiens we're all human beings that have our

upsides and our downsides our upside is we
built a Colosseum our downside is we ruin

it oh my god OK anyways now look recently
we had the ISIS destroying the Museums and

the ancient artwork and the sculptures in
Mosel and other places in Iraq and it was

gut wrenching we showed the video and I could
hardly look at the video this is not anywhere

near the same level I mean they just pulverized
priceless parts of our history our human history

that were over 3,000 years old right but dude
like you knuckleheads you're not ISIS you're

not doing it maliciously I hope right but
you're chipping away at it literally right

yeah you wouldn't going into a museum and
scratch a painting right and so could you

imagine like dude let's put our initials in
the Mona Lisa it'll be cool look I think part

of it is just the environment you're in part
of it is the nature of the art or the historical

structure so you look at the Colosseum in
Rome and it's ruins right it's ruins so I

think a lot of people think oh it's not a
big deal and I know that it's true of the

pyramids as well I mean I've had a lot of
people tell me that pyramids will have graffiti

on them or people will do something to you
know destroy them basically and it's stupid

you can have that mentality this is so important
it's such a huge part of ancient Rome the

history you want to learn about these things
and you don't want to destroy it and by the

way even if it was just a random wall right
first of all you freaking lady you women you're

in our twenties you're not like a 12-year-old
why are you carving your initial in anything

even it was a random wall even if it was a
piece of fruit grow the hell up look I think

some people make the absurd argument this
is part of living history that we'll also

be part of the ruins get out of here and throughout
all the years the different people that have

marketed their initials in there you know
that's part of the living history I'm probably

giving them too much credit they probably
didn't even both thinking of that bullshit

excuse no they thought like oh my god here
we are it's Rome the ruins let's put our initials

and take a selfie like that's what they were
thinking grow the fuck up grow the fuck up

you're I your twenties or they thought when
it Rome don't do it you're a child I know

OK don't do it it's stupid and it's not just
Roman history it's not just that you're defacing

things that are priceless in Italy it's all
of our history and so it's a profoundly selfish

act to destroy all of our history you don't
have the right to do that

title: Tourists Who Vandalized Roman Colosseum Faces Jail Time And HUGE Fine

comments.text:
If I was in charge in Italy the court case result would go something like 
this:

1. Mandatory prison sentence of not less than 5 years for defacing 
historical monuments.
2. the tourists' assets back home in their home country, frozen to help pay 
for their prison sentence.
3. 'ban for life' from re-entering the country.
4, Where the evidence is unquestionable and unequivocal, there is no right 
of appeal.﻿
comments.author: Villaver and White

comments.text:
Years ago I went to an art museum with my college art class. We walk in the 
door, to my right are ancient Egyptian artifacts, I am literally breathless 
at being around something that old and so amazing.

10 seconds later I am breathless for another reason, one of the idiots I am 
with picked up one of the pieces and posed for a picture while his buddy 
snapped away.

Just telling the story I am in shock all over again. What happened to 
people? Why did it happen?﻿

I have to confess, I took a small piece of the colosseum as a souvenier.  I 
didn't break it off of the colosseum, though.  I was just a small piece 
that had broken off of one of the walls and was lying on the ground, and I 
just picked it up and put it in my pocket.

I felt kind of guilty, but I figured it would just get kicked around until 
it was indistinguishable from a normal rock anyways.  It's not like someone 
would have actually reattached it to the colosseum.﻿

comments.author: Clariselol

comments.text:
I studied archaeology and a great deal about Roman History.  I have also 
been to the Colosseum and done some university led excavations around Rome. 
 I have to say that I have mixed feelings on this.  While they are 
definitely defacing priceless history it is hard to ignore the significance 
of graffiti in Italy.  Italy is covered in graffiti.  They rarely remove it 
because it is considered a form of art by most Italians.  This form of art 
in Italian culture predates the Colosseum itself by several hundred years 
easily.  So "When in Rome" is a valid argument here to a certain degree. 
 Anywhere you look on the stone of the Colosseum you will see peoples 
initials carved.  My personal opinion is that these girls didn't make any 
kind of real art, and I doubt they knew much about the history of Roman 
graffiti.  I would imagine these are the real reasons for their being 
arrested more so than it being a general act of vandalism.  Because as I 
said, Italy has been vandalizing itself head to toe for thousands of years, 
and generally accepts or ignores it. ﻿
